subject: Re: Exception Handling Question
msgSnippet: I agree with your model for this type of test case.. but why catch unexpected exceptions?  Seems much cleaner to just let them propagate and let JUnit take
messageBody:
I agree with your model for this type of test case.. but why catch
unexpected exceptions? Seems much cleaner to just let them propagate
and let JUnit take care of reporting the failure.

I always declare my test cases as "throws Exception" for this
reason...

Kevin

--- In junit@egroups.com, Robert Sartin <sartin@a...> wrote:
>
> --- G Ramasubramani <grama@a...> wrote:
> > In this case however, it is a user defined exception and
> > hence I know what message to expect. What would be a proper course
of
> > action in case it is a system level exception?
>
>
> Here's what I do:
>
> try {
> objectUnderTest.failMethod();
> fail("failMethod call did not get exception");
> }
> catch (ExpectedException e) {
> // Nothing, all is well
> // If e has instance data, might check it
> }
> // Catch any unexpected checked exceptions and fail()
>
> I like fail() better than assert(false) since it expresses intent.
>
> I don't bother to check the message of the exception since the class
is
> usually enough and the message is potentially unstable in the
presence
> of changes elsewhere. However, if the exception contains other data
I
> might check that. A notable example: for RemoteException I would
> probably at least check the type of the detail.
>
> Regards,
>
> Rob
